Authors: Farzaneh Badali, Masoud Abrinbana, Jafar Abdollahzadeh
Title:
Morphological and molecular taxonomy of Pythium monoclinum,
sp. nov., and P. iranense, sp. nov., from Iran
Keywords:
Oomycota, Peronosporomycetes, phylogeny, Pythiaceae, new
species
Abstract:
Two new species of Pythium Pringsheim isolated from soils
of northwestern regions in Iran, are described: P. monoclinum, sp. nov.,
and P. iranense, sp. nov. Both species are morphologically distinct from
all known species. Pythium monoclinum, sp. nov., is morphologically
characterized by the pres¬ence of a swollen element in oogonial stalks
below terminal oogonia, mostly monoclinous antheridia originating at
various distances from the oogonia that occasionally arising from
inflated part of oogo¬nial stalk and, rarely production of peanut-shaped
and double oospores. Pythium iranense, sp. nov., is distinguished from
other species of the genus by the production of smooth-walled oogonia
that occasionally have 1-3 papillae, globose to rarely elongated
oogonia, 1-2(-5) antheridia per oogonium or crowd of antheridia around
oogonia, 1-2 rarely 3-4 oospores per oogonium, rarely peanut-shaped
oospores and immature oospores provided with 1-6 projections.
Phylogenetic relationships of the isolates belonging to these new
species with other related species were investigated using internal
transcribed spacers of rRNA genes and partial cytochrome c oxidase
subunit I sequence data. The phylogenetic analyses separated the two
species from closely related species and placed P. iranense, sp. nov.,
in clade J1 but the clade of P. monoclinum, sp. nov., was unknown.
